p.s: But in his argumentation Worne is methods of persuasion to steer the reader in a particular direction and convince him of his opinion.

It intends to make the reader feel that the UK's general public shows to interest in learning foreign languages.
In contrast to that he advises the readers to re-commissioning our collective brains(l. 5), adviering a positive connotation to the act of choosing more foreign language studies.
Also this implies that there already is a general interest in these topics but it has to be reactivated.
Following this he gives a statistic that states that 10.000 fewer language A-Level exams were taken last year than at the end of the 1990s(ll. 9f.).
But this number is not very high considering the number of students, the long timespan and higher participation in GCSE-level exams which are not considered.
With the high number of 10.000 Worne wants to give his readers the impression of a big decline in foreign language studies.
The authors makes an extensive use of the parentheses (cf. ll. 6f., ll. 13f., l. 32) in order to weaken counter arguments like in line 6f. where he belittles to pregres in primary schools.
By saying that there's a long haul ahead (l. 7) the readers get the impresion that there is almost no development yet.
Furthermore Worne builds himself as the expert in the topic.
In line 13f. he regutes contrary opinion and backs up with the colloquial term Cobblers (l. 15).
He marks his opponentsopposing arguments as nonsense, the reader is troughthrough the effect indrectlyindirectly advised to not pay any further attention to those opposing claims.
Also he calls those with opposing opinions perfectly intelligent people in an irony.
As he expects the reader to get the opposite impressisionimpression through it also being a hyperbole.
The same stylistic devices are used later (cf. ll. 14f.) where Worne presents his contraries always having a solution as comedic so that they less believable to the reader became.
With oppositions (cf. ll 20ff., l. 26) Worne says how things should be (l. 26) or how things are.
With the parallelism and klimaxclimax in the lines 16ff. the necessity of foreign language skills for the UK's economy are underlined.
There is an emphasis on language through the alliteration language learning (l. 16) and an anaphora (cf. ll. 16f.).
The enumeration of national traits of employs the impression of a high mee of languages and how they are essential (l. 17).
This impression is aided by the fact that words like prosperity (l. 16) have a very positive connotation.
The same is to be found in line 27 withewith an additional language to a profession is more attractive to employers (l. 27).
The mentioning of the employers is like when Worne refers to the CBI/Peasan Education and Skills Survey (l. 19) as an authority supporting his claims.

It achieves even though they might only agree in that particular point to the author that the reader gets the impression that other experts share Worne's opinion what makes him more believeablebelievable down the line.
Finally Worne employs the inclusive pronouns we (l. 33) and us (l. 35).
They make the reader relate more to the topic and make them feel more included so that they accept the described problems as their own and fall more easily to Worne's proposed solution.
Especially considering the tough reality in thaughtough job market.
Considering all these factors it is clear that only through these techniques of persuasion Worne can achieve his goal of spreading his opinion and allowing him to make broad claims (cf. ll. 30f.)
